Hi everyone,
 
I’ll be anchoring a special hour-long
  broadcast of the CBS Evening News tonight from Blacksburg, Virginia, where earlier
  today a gunman opened fire multiple times on the Virginia Tech University
  campus, resulting in the deadliest campus massacre in U.S. history. Our team
  of correspondents will bring you complete coverage.
 
We will start by telling you about the incidents
  that began unfolding at 7:15 this morning in one of the largest residence
  halls on the Virginia Tech campus and continued two hours later at Norris Hall,
  an engineering building. By late morning, at least 31 on campus were dead. President
  Bush said he was “horrified” by the news of the shooting, and
  expressed his sympathy for the victims and their families. Thalia Assuras will
  talk with some of the students who survived the shooting and have more
  eyewitness accounts.
 
Daniel Sieberg, our science and technology correspondent,
  will detail how the university and the students who study there used Internet
  communications to keep one another informed as the tragedy unfolded.
 
And in the wake of such a massacre, it is natural to
  ask “could this have been prevented?” Hari Sreenivasan will
  report on the state of security on campuses around the country.
 
In the meantime, residents of the Northeast are
  coping with the remnants of a massive storm that hit over the weekend,
  bringing record rainfall and strong winds. By Monday afternoon, much of the
  East Coast was still under water and hundreds of thousands of people were
  without electricity. Nancy Cordes will have the story.
 
The National Urban League is releasing a report tomorrow
  that will show that black men in America don’t have many of
  the same privileges as other citizens. We’ll have the study’s
  findings tonight.
 
I hope you’ll join us. In the meantime, stay
  updated on news out of Virginia
  by visiting CBSNews.com.
 
Thanks,




Katie Couric
CouricandCo@cbs.com
